subsection_content:
Pyelonephritis often occurs when bacteria invade and cause infection, the most common agents being gram-negative bacteria (1)
1. Acute pyelonephritis
Acute pyelonephritis is a fairly common urinary tract infection, causing sudden and severe symptoms. Bacteria can travel back from the bladder up the ureters to the renal pelvis or enter the bloodstream when the patient has sepsis. If not treated promptly, it can lead to death.
2. Chronic pyelonephritis
Chronic pyelonephritis is a condition of chronic damage to the parenchyma and interstitium of the kidney, and is the result of repeated or persistent pyelonephritis in the kidney, causing destruction and fibrosis. kidney damage, leading to kidney failure.
The chronic form is rare, but is frequently seen in children or people with acquired or congenital urinary tract obstruction.
